Article.ArticleTitle: Effect of Sodium Flouride Mouthwash and Ozone-Infused Oil Pulling Solution With Coconut Oil on Mechanical Properties and Surface Characterization of Copper-Nickel-Titanium Orthodontic Archwires.

AbstractText: To determine the impact on the mechanical properties and surface characteristics of prefabricated 0.016" copper-nickel-titanium (Cu-Ni-Ti) type 35<sup>o</sup>C (Ormco Company, USA) archwires when subjected to 0.05% sodium fluoride (NaF) mouthwash (ACT Anti-Cavity Fluoride Mouthwash, Sanofi Company, USA) and ozone-infused oil-pulling solution with coconut oil (O<sub>3</sub>) (O<sub>3</sub> Essentials, Health Ranger Store, USA).

Sixty samples of preformed maxillary 0.016" Cu-Ni-Ti archwires were cut at the straight posterior ends for a length of 25 mm and then equally distributed into three groups (n=20). Each group of wires was immersed in distilled water (dH<sub>2</sub>O), NaF, and O<sub>3</sub> solutions for 90 minutes at 37<sup>o</sup>C. All samples were taken out of their solutions and washed with distilled water prior to testing. On a universal testing device, a three-point bending test was performed on 15 samples. Yield strength (YS), flexural modulus of elasticity (E), and springback ratio (YS/E) were calculated. The remaining five samples from respective solutions were observed under a scanning electron microscope (SEM) for surface topography evaluation.

The mean differences in loading YS, E, and YS/E between NaF and O<sub>3</sub> are 41.14 MPa, 4.58 GPa, and -0.0006 whereas unloading values are 23.45 MPa, 4.38 GPa, and -0.0004, respectively with a statistical significance of <0.001. Surface topography alteration was appreciated in the NaF mouthwash group compared to the O<sub>3</sub> solution.

The mechanical properties of 0.016" Cu-Ni-Ti archwires during loading and unloading were changed after exposure to NaF mouthwash and O<sub>3</sub> solution. The mechanical properties of Cu-Ni-Ti archwires were more negatively affected by NaF mouthwash than by O<sub>3</sub> solution. Sodium fluoride mouthwash offers more corrosive changes when compared with the O<sub>3</sub> solution.
